title: 1 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who did David meet at Nob according to 1 Samuel 21:1?
options: Ahimelech the priest
Saul the king
Achish the king of Gath
Doeg the Edomite
questions.correctAnswer: Ahimelech the priest
questions.explanation: David came to Nob and met Ahimelech the priest as stated in 1 Samuel 21:1.

questions.question: Why was Ahimelech afraid when he saw David alone? (1 Samuel 21:1)
options: Because David was alone without any men
Because he saw a sword
Because Saul was coming
Because the temple was being attacked
questions.correctAnswer: Because David was alone without any men
questions.explanation: Ahimelech was afraid because David was alone and had no men with him, as noted in 1 Samuel 21:1.

questions.question: What reason did David give Ahimelech for being alone? (1 Samuel 21:2)
options: The king hath commanded me a business
I was hunting alone
I was hiding from Saul
I was traveling to Gath
questions.correctAnswer: The king hath commanded me a business
questions.explanation: David told Ahimelech that the king had commanded him on a secret business, as recorded in 1 Samuel 21:2.

questions.question: What did David ask Ahimelech to give him? (1 Samuel 21:3)
options: Five loaves of bread
A sword
Water to drink
A horse
questions.correctAnswer: Five loaves of bread
questions.explanation: David requested five loaves of bread from Ahimelech according to 1 Samuel 21:3.

questions.question: What type of bread did Ahimelech say he had on hand? (1 Samuel 21:4)
options: Hallowed bread
Common bread
Barley bread
Unleavened bread
questions.correctAnswer: Hallowed bread
questions.explanation: Ahimelech told David that he had no common bread, only hallowed bread, as stated in 1 Samuel 21:4.

questions.question: True or False: David claimed that the young men had kept themselves from women for three days. (1 Samuel 21:5)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David said that women had been kept from them about three days, making the bread 'in a manner common,' as in 1 Samuel 21:5.

questions.question: What bread did the priest finally give to David? (1 Samuel 21:6)
options: Hallowed bread from the shewbread
Common bread
Barley loaves
Unleavened bread
questions.correctAnswer: Hallowed bread from the shewbread
questions.explanation: The priest gave David the hallowed bread, which was the shewbread taken from before the LORD, as described in 1 Samuel 21:6.

questions.question: Who was Doeg, mentioned in 1 Samuel 21:7?
options: An Edomite and chief herdman of Saul
A servant of David
The king of Gath
A priest at Nob
questions.correctAnswer: An Edomite and chief herdman of Saul
questions.explanation: Doeg was an Edomite, the chief herdman belonging to Saul, according to 1 Samuel 21:7.

questions.question: What weapon did David ask Ahimelech about? (1 Samuel 21:8)
options: Spear or sword
Bow and arrow
Shield
Dagger
questions.correctAnswer: Spear or sword
questions.explanation: David asked if there was a spear or sword under Ahimelech’s hand, as recorded in 1 Samuel 21:8.

questions.question: What sword did Ahimelech show David? (1 Samuel 21:9)
options: The sword of Goliath the Philistine
Saul’s sword
A common sword
David’s own sword
questions.correctAnswer: The sword of Goliath the Philistine
questions.explanation: Ahimelech showed David the sword of Goliath, which David had slain, as in 1 Samuel 21:9.

questions.question: Where did David flee to for fear of Saul? (1 Samuel 21:10)
options: Achish the king of Gath
Nob
Jerusalem
Ramath-lehi
questions.correctAnswer: Achish the king of Gath
questions.explanation: David fled to Achish the king of Gath out of fear of Saul, as stated in 1 Samuel 21:10.

questions.question: What did the servants of Achish say about David? (1 Samuel 21:11)
options: He was the king of the land
He was a mad man
He was a shepherd
He was a servant of Saul
questions.correctAnswer: He was the king of the land
questions.explanation: The servants of Achish identified David as the king of the land, according to 1 Samuel 21:11.

questions.question: True or False: David was not afraid of Achish the king of Gath. (1 Samuel 21:12)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David was sore afraid of Achish, as noted in 1 Samuel 21:12.

questions.question: How did David behave before the servants of Achish? (1 Samuel 21:13)
options: Feigned himself mad
Danced joyfully
Sang a song
Fought bravely
questions.correctAnswer: Feigned himself mad
questions.explanation: David pretended to be mad by scrabbling on the doors and letting his spittle fall upon his beard, as described in 1 Samuel 21:13.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Samuel 21:14: 'Lo, ye see the man is _______'
options: mad
brave
wise
strong
questions.correctAnswer: mad
questions.explanation: Achish said to his servants, 'Lo, ye see the man is mad' in 1 Samuel 21:14.

questions.question: True or False: Achish wanted the mad man to come into his house. (1 Samuel 21:15)
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Achish questioned why they brought a mad man and said he did not want such a fellow in his house, as in 1 Samuel 21:15.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling afraid and alone in their service to God. Based on 1 Samuel 21:1, how can David's interaction with Ahimelech teach us about faith and trust in God during solitude?
options: David sought help from a faithful servant of God even when alone
David ignored others and trusted only in himself
David fled immediately without seeking counsel
David confronted Ahimelech angrily for questioning him
questions.correctAnswer: David sought help from a faithful servant of God even when alone
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 21:1, David comes alone to Ahimelech the priest, showing that even in solitude, he sought fellowship and support from God's servants. This teaches us to trust God and His people in moments of loneliness.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 21:2 demonstrate the importance of integrity and honesty in our work and relationships?
options: David truthfully explains the king’s secret business to Ahimelech
David lies openly about his mission
David refuses to speak to Ahimelech about his task
David commands Ahimelech without explanation
questions.correctAnswer: David truthfully explains the king’s secret business to Ahimelech
questions.explanation: David honestly shares that the king sent him on a secret mission (1 Samuel 21:2), showing integrity even when dealing with sensitive matters, which is important for trustworthy relationships and work ethic.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship can we learn from David’s request for bread in 1 Samuel 21:3?
options: David seeks to use resources responsibly by asking for what is available
David takes bread without asking
David demands lavish provisions
David refuses to eat any bread
questions.correctAnswer: David seeks to use resources responsibly by asking for what is available
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 21:3, David asks Ahimelech for what was at hand, showing respect for resources and stewardship, teaching us to be content and responsible with what God provides.

questions.question: A believer asks about maintaining holiness in daily life. What does Ahimelech’s condition about the bread in 1 Samuel 21:4 teach us about spiritual discipline?
options: The bread was holy and only for those who kept themselves pure
The bread was common and available to all
The bread was magical and had no conditions
The bread was cursed for anyone who touched it
questions.correctAnswer: The bread was holy and only for those who kept themselves pure
questions.explanation: Ahimelech explains the bread was hallowed and only for those who had kept themselves from women (1 Samuel 21:4), emphasizing the biblical value of holiness and self-discipline in daily living.

questions.question: How does David’s response in 1 Samuel 21:5 model humility and respect for God’s instructions in our spiritual walk?
options: David honestly states they have kept themselves and that the bread is acceptable
David lies to get the bread
David refuses to accept the conditions
David scolds the priest for the restrictions
questions.correctAnswer: David honestly states they have kept themselves and that the bread is acceptable
questions.explanation: David acknowledges their purity and accepts the bread as sanctified (1 Samuel 21:5), demonstrating humility and obedience to God’s standards in everyday life.

questions.question: What does the priest giving David the hallowed bread in 1 Samuel 21:6 teach about God’s provision in times of need?
options: God provides even through sacred means when there is no common provision
God withholds provision in difficult times
David steals the bread secretly
The bread had no significance
questions.correctAnswer: God provides even through sacred means when there is no common provision
questions.explanation: The priest gives David the shewbread, which was normally reserved for priests (1 Samuel 21:6), illustrating God’s gracious provision even in unusual circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: Doeg the Edomite was a servant of Saul who was present when David visited Ahimelech (1 Samuel 21:7).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:7 states that Doeg, an Edomite and chief of Saul’s herdmen, was present that day, which highlights the presence of observers even in private moments.

questions.question: What virtue is taught by David’s request for a weapon in 1 Samuel 21:8, despite not bringing any himself?
options: Preparedness and seeking protection while trusting God
Recklessness and ignoring danger
Self-sufficiency without help
Disrespect for the king’s commands
questions.correctAnswer: Preparedness and seeking protection while trusting God
questions.explanation: David asks for a sword or spear because he has none due to haste (1 Samuel 21:8), showing the balance of trusting God and taking practical steps for safety.

questions.question: How does the sword of Goliath symbolize God’s past deliverance and encourage perseverance according to 1 Samuel 21:9?
options: It reminds David of God’s power in past victories, encouraging faith
It is just an ordinary weapon with no significance
David refuses to accept it
The sword is a source of fear and doubt
questions.correctAnswer: It reminds David of God’s power in past victories, encouraging faith
questions.explanation: The sword of Goliath, kept by the priest (1 Samuel 21:9), symbolizes God’s deliverance and strengthens David’s confidence to face trials.

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 21:10, what biblical principle can we learn about fleeing from danger and trusting God’s timing?
options: David fled for fear of Saul, illustrating that sometimes retreat is wise
David fought Saul head-on without fear
David ignored danger and stayed in Nob
David confronted Saul boldly at once
questions.correctAnswer: David fled for fear of Saul, illustrating that sometimes retreat is wise
questions.explanation: David’s flight to Achish king of Gath (1 Samuel 21:10) shows that trusting God sometimes means prudently withdrawing from threat until the right time.

questions.question: True or False: The servants of Achish recognized David and praised his reputation as a mighty warrior (1 Samuel 21:11).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 21:11, Achish’s servants recall songs praising David’s great victories, showing that a good reputation for faithfulness and courage is important.

questions.question: What does David’s fear of Achish in 1 Samuel 21:12 teach us about humility and prudence in difficult situations?
options: David was cautious and humble, recognizing danger
David showed arrogance and defiance
David ignored the threat
David immediately attacked Achish
questions.correctAnswer: David was cautious and humble, recognizing danger
questions.explanation: David’s fear of Achish (1 Samuel 21:12) models humility and prudence, reminding believers to be wise and careful in trials.

questions.question: A believer struggles with how to act when misunderstood. What does David’s feigning madness in 1 Samuel 21:13 teach about perseverance and creative witness?
options: David used wisdom and creativity to protect himself without sinning
David gave up and confessed defeat
David became angry and violent
David lied to Achish in a harmful way
questions.correctAnswer: David used wisdom and creativity to protect himself without sinning
questions.explanation: David’s feigned madness (1 Samuel 21:13) shows using wisdom and ingenuity to persevere and survive trials without compromising integrity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Achish said to his servants, 'Lo, ye see the man is mad: wherefore then have ye ______ him to me?' (1 Samuel 21:14)
options: brought
hidden
blessed
ignored
questions.correctAnswer: brought
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 21:14, Achish questions why the servants have brought David to him since he appears mad, teaching about discernment in leadership and fellowship.

questions.question: What lesson about contentment and humility in trials can be drawn from Achish’s words in 1 Samuel 21:15?
options: Achish questions the need for mad men in his house, showing the need for wise company
Achish welcomes all regardless of condition
Achish praises David’s madness
Achish ignores David completely
questions.correctAnswer: Achish questions the need for mad men in his house, showing the need for wise company
questions.explanation: Achish’s reluctance to have David in his house (1 Samuel 21:15) teaches us to seek wise and godly fellowship and to be content with God’s guidance in difficult social situations.

questions.question: How does David’s interaction with Ahimelech throughout 1 Samuel 21 teach about reliance on God’s servants and church fellowship?
options: David seeks the priest’s help, showing the importance of seeking counsel and fellowship
David avoids all church leaders
David acts independently without support
David disrespects the priest
questions.correctAnswer: David seeks the priest’s help, showing the importance of seeking counsel and fellowship
questions.explanation: David’s visit to Ahimelech (1 Samuel 21:1-6) models dependence on God’s servants and fellowship, emphasizing the biblical principle of church community and support in trials.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 21.

questions.question: Why was Ahimelech the priest afraid when David came to Nob alone?
options: Because David was alone without his men
Because Ahimelech was disobedient to the king
Because David carried the sword of Goliath
Because Doeg the Edomite was present
questions.correctAnswer: Because David was alone without his men
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:1 states that Ahimelech was afraid because David came alone and no man was with him, which was unusual and caused fear.

questions.question: What reason did David give Ahimelech for why he was alone and secretive about his mission?
options: The king commanded secrecy and appointed his servants elsewhere
He was fleeing from Saul
He was on a diplomatic mission to the Philistines
He wanted to test the priest's loyalty
questions.correctAnswer: The king commanded secrecy and appointed his servants elsewhere
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:2 records David explaining to Ahimelech that the king commanded him on a secret business and that his servants were sent to another place.

questions.question: What type of bread did Ahimelech offer David, and under what condition could it be eaten?
options: Hallowed bread, only if the young men kept themselves from women
Common bread available to all
Unleavened bread for ceremonial use
Barley bread reserved for the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Hallowed bread, only if the young men kept themselves from women
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 21:4, Ahimelech said there was no common bread but hallowed bread, which could only be given if the young men had kept themselves from women.

questions.question: How did David justify eating the hallowed bread despite the usual restrictions?
options: He said the young men had been kept from women for three days, so the bread was as common as if sanctified that day
He claimed a special priestly status
He argued that Saul had commanded it
He said it was an emergency situation
questions.correctAnswer: He said the young men had been kept from women for three days, so the bread was as common as if sanctified that day
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:5 shows David explaining the young men had abstained from women for three days, making the bread effectively common for them.

questions.question: What bread did the priest ultimately give David?
options: Hallowed bread (the shewbread)
Common bread from the storehouse
Freshly baked barley loaves
Unleavened ceremonial bread
questions.correctAnswer: Hallowed bread (the shewbread)
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 21:6, the priest gave David the hallowed shewbread because there was no other bread available.

questions.question: Who was Doeg the Edomite, mentioned in this chapter?
options: Saul's chief herdman and a servant present at Nob
A Philistine warrior allied to Achish
A Levite priest in Nob
David's loyal companion
questions.correctAnswer: Saul's chief herdman and a servant present at Nob
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:7 identifies Doeg as an Edomite servant of Saul and the chief herdman who was present at Nob that day.

questions.question: What weapon did David request from Ahimelech and why was it significant?
options: The sword of Goliath, which David had slain
A spear used previously by King Saul
A dagger for close combat
A bow and arrows for hunting
questions.correctAnswer: The sword of Goliath, which David had slain
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:9 reveals that David requested the sword of Goliath, the Philistine he had killed, as there was no other sword available to him.

questions.question: Why did David not bring his own weapons with him to Nob?
options: Because the king's business required haste
He lost them in battle
He gave them to his servants
He wanted to rely on divine protection
questions.correctAnswer: Because the king's business required haste
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:8 explains David's reason for not bringing his sword or weapons was due to the urgency of the king's business.

questions.question: Where did David flee after leaving Nob and why?
options: To Achish king of Gath, for fear of Saul
To Bethlehem to seek refuge with his family
To the wilderness of Ziph to hide
To the Philistine city of Ekron for protection
questions.correctAnswer: To Achish king of Gath, for fear of Saul
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:10 states David fled to Achish king of Gath because he was afraid of Saul.

questions.question: What did the servants of Achish say about David upon seeing him?
options: They recognized him as a mighty warrior who killed ten thousands
They thought he was a common thief
They believed he was mad from the desert
They mistook him for a Philistine spy
questions.correctAnswer: They recognized him as a mighty warrior who killed ten thousands
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:11 recounts the servants mentioning David's fame for killing ten thousands, comparing him to Saul who killed thousands.

questions.question: How did David respond to the fear of Achish's servants recognizing him?
options: He was sore afraid and laid up their words in his heart
He challenged them to a duel
He revealed his true identity and asked for refuge
He fled immediately to the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: He was sore afraid and laid up their words in his heart
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:12 states David was very afraid of Achish and kept the servants' words in his heart.

questions.question: What action did David take to protect himself in Gath?
options: He feigned madness to avoid harm
He hid in a cave outside the city
He pretended to be a Philistine soldier
He bribed the guards
questions.correctAnswer: He feigned madness to avoid harm
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 21:13, David pretended to be mad by scrabbling on the doors and letting spittle fall on his beard.

questions.question: What was Achish's reaction to David's feigned madness?
options: He questioned why David was brought to him if he was mad
He ordered David to be imprisoned
He welcomed David into his house
He sent David back to Saul
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why David was brought to him if he was mad
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:14-15 shows Achish telling his servants that David was mad and asking why they brought a madman to him.

questions.question: The bread David ate at Nob is often seen as a type of which New Testament event?
options: Jesus sharing the bread at the Last Supper
The feeding of the 5000 with loaves and fishes
The manna given to Israel in the wilderness
The miraculous catch of fish
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus sharing the bread at the Last Supper
questions.explanation: The hallowed shewbread, taken from before the LORD and eaten by David, foreshadows Jesus offering bread in the Last Supper as a symbol of His body (cf. Matthew 26:26).

questions.question: True or False: The sword David took from Ahimelech was an ordinary weapon kept in the temple.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 21:9 states the sword was that of Goliath, a unique prize David had acquired, not an ordinary temple weapon.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason did David give Ahimelech the priest for coming alone and without his men?
options: The king hath commanded me a business, and hath said let no man know
I was sent alone by Saul to test your loyalty
I have been rejected by my men
I came secretly to avoid enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The king hath commanded me a business, and hath said let no man know
questions.explanation: David explained to Ahimelech that the king had given him a secret mission and instructed him to come alone (1 Samuel 21:2). This shows David’s obedience and the secretive nature of his mission. This aligns with biblical themes of obedience to authority (Romans 13:1-2), God’s providence in hiding plans (Psalm 31:20), and the necessity of faith in God’s direction (Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: What type of bread did Ahimelech give David when common bread was not available?
options: Hallowed bread
Ordinary bread
Barley bread
Unleavened bread
questions.correctAnswer: Hallowed bread
questions.explanation: Ahimelech gave David hallowed bread, the consecrated bread normally reserved for priests (1 Samuel 21:6). This act foreshadows Christ as the Bread of Life (John 6:35) and reveals God's provision through sacred objects. It also reflects the holiness required before God (Leviticus 10:10) and Jesus’ teaching on mercy over ritual (Matthew 12:3-4).

questions.question: What condition did Ahimelech place on the use of the hallowed bread?
options: The young men must have kept themselves from women
Only priests could eat it
It could only be eaten on the Sabbath
It was only for the king's use
questions.correctAnswer: The young men must have kept themselves from women
questions.explanation: Ahimelech specified that the bread could only be given if the young men had kept themselves from women, reflecting the Old Testament purity laws (1 Samuel 21:4). This highlights the holiness required to partake in sacred things (Leviticus 15:18), the principle of sanctification (1 Corinthians 6:18-20), and the importance of purity before God (Hebrews 12:14).

questions.question: Which notable weapon did Ahimelech offer David, and what was its significance?
options: The sword of Goliath, symbolizing David’s victory over the Philistine
A spear belonging to Saul
A ceremonial dagger used in sacrifices
A bow given by Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: The sword of Goliath, symbolizing David’s victory over the Philistine
questions.explanation: Ahimelech offered David the sword of Goliath, which he had slain, symbolizing God's deliverance and David’s role as a divinely empowered warrior (1 Samuel 21:9). This foreshadows Christ’s victory over evil (Colossians 2:15), God’s empowerment of His servants (Ephesians 6:17), and the triumph of faith over worldly powers (Revelation 12:11).

questions.question: Why did David claim he had not brought his sword or weapons with him?
options: Because the king's business required haste
He had given them to his men
He intended to rely on God alone
He had lost them in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because the king's business required haste
questions.explanation: David told Ahimelech he did not bring weapons because the king's business was urgent and required haste (1 Samuel 21:8). This illustrates God's providential timing (Ecclesiastes 3:1), the urgency of obedience (Luke 9:59-60), and reliance on God’s protection rather than human strength (Psalm 20:7).

questions.question: Who was Doeg, and what role did he play in this chapter?
options: An Edomite servant of Saul present during David's visit to Ahimelech
A Philistine warrior allied with Achish
A prophet who warned David
A Levite priest assisting Ahimelech
questions.correctAnswer: An Edomite servant of Saul present during David's visit to Ahimelech
questions.explanation: Doeg was an Edomite servant of Saul and the chief of his herdmen, present when David met Ahimelech (1 Samuel 21:7). His presence highlights human sinfulness and betrayal (Psalm 41:9), the danger of disloyalty (2 Samuel 16:20-23), and the consequences of fear leading to violence (Proverbs 29:25).

questions.question: To whom did David flee after leaving Nob, and what was his reason?
options: King Achish of Gath, due to fear of Saul
Saul’s palace, to seek forgiveness
The wilderness of Judah, to hide
The city of Jerusalem, for protection
questions.correctAnswer: King Achish of Gath, due to fear of Saul
questions.explanation: David fled to Achish, king of Gath, because he feared Saul’s pursuit (1 Samuel 21:10). This reflects the theme of divine protection amidst trials (Psalm 34:17-19), the testing of faith (James 1:2-4), and the paradox of seeking refuge among enemies (Psalm 18:2).

questions.question: What did the servants of Achish say upon seeing David, and what theological implication does this have?
options: They recognized him as a mighty warrior, praising his victories
They accused him of being a spy for Saul
They ignored him as insignificant
They welcomed him as a peace envoy
questions.correctAnswer: They recognized him as a mighty warrior, praising his victories
questions.explanation: Achish’s servants identified David as a celebrated warrior, noting his greater success than Saul (1 Samuel 21:11). This shows the recognition of God’s empowerment (Exodus 17:11-13), the role of God’s anointed leader (Psalm 2:2-4), and the tension between human praise and divine sovereignty (John 7:18).

questions.question: How did David respond to the fear of being recognized by Achish’s servants?
options: He was sore afraid and changed his behavior, feigning madness
He boldly declared his innocence
He fled immediately
He prayed aloud for deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: He was sore afraid and changed his behavior, feigning madness
questions.explanation: David feigned madness to avoid harm, showing human vulnerability and reliance on God’s providence (1 Samuel 21:12-13). This act reveals the tension between human fear and divine trust (Psalm 56:3-4), the wisdom in certain deceptions for survival (Ecclesiastes 3:7), and God’s protection over His servant (Psalm 91:4).

questions.question: What specific actions did David perform to appear mad before Achish’s servants?
options: Scrabbled on the doors of the gate and let his spittle fall on his beard
Laughed uncontrollably and shouted loudly
Danced wildly and sang incoherently
Fell silent and stared blankly
questions.correctAnswer: Scrabbled on the doors of the gate and let his spittle fall on his beard
questions.explanation: David’s behavior included scratching the doors and letting his saliva fall on his beard (1 Samuel 21:13), actions meant to convince others he was mad. This illustrates the human instinct for self-preservation (Proverbs 22:3), the use of wisdom in adversity (Matthew 10:16), and God’s sovereignty over even desperate actions (Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What was King Achish’s reaction to David’s feigned madness?
options: He questioned why they brought a mad man to him and declined to have him in his house
He ordered David to be imprisoned
He welcomed David as a prophet
He sent David away peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why they brought a mad man to him and declined to have him in his house
questions.explanation: Achish recognized David’s madness and questioned why he was brought before him, refusing to have him in his house (1 Samuel 21:14-15). This reaction underscores human discernment, the rejection of disorder (1 Corinthians 14:33), and the limits of earthly protection compared to God’s care (Psalm 46:1).

questions.question: Why was the shewbread considered 'hallowed' and normally off-limits to anyone but priests?
options: It was consecrated bread placed before the LORD and reserved for priests
It was specially baked only on the Sabbath
It was a symbol of the covenant with Israel
It was made from rare grains
questions.correctAnswer: It was consecrated bread placed before the LORD and reserved for priests
questions.explanation: The shewbread was holy bread placed before the LORD in the tabernacle and eaten only by priests (Leviticus 24:5-9, 1 Samuel 21:6). This reflects holiness required by God (Exodus 29:33), the typology of Christ as the Bread of Life (John 6:51), and the principle of sacred service (Hebrews 7:26-27).

questions.question: How does David’s request for bread and weapons illustrate the human need for both spiritual and physical provision?
options: He asked for bread to sustain life and a sword for protection
He only sought food, showing reliance on God alone
He requested gold and silver for bribery
He demanded a chariot for battle
questions.correctAnswer: He asked for bread to sustain life and a sword for protection
questions.explanation: David’s request for bread and the sword of Goliath demonstrates the biblical truth that God provides for both physical needs (Matthew 6:11) and protection (Psalm 18:2). It highlights the integration of faith and practical action (James 2:14-17) and God’s sovereignty over all aspects of life (Colossians 1:17).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by David’s fear of Saul and subsequent flight?
options: The tension between divine election and human suffering
The triumph of human power over God’s will
The rejection of faith in times of trial
The certainty of earthly kingship over God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The tension between divine election and human suffering
questions.explanation: David’s fear and flight illustrate the tension between God’s chosen servant enduring suffering (Psalm 34:19), the testing of faith (1 Peter 1:6-7), and God’s ultimate sovereignty in salvation history (Romans 8:28). It emphasizes that election does not exempt from hardship, a major biblical theme (Hebrews 11:36-38).

questions.question: How does David’s interaction with Ahimelech reveal the priestly role in supporting God’s anointed?
options: Ahimelech provides spiritual resources and counsel to David
Ahimelech refuses to assist David
Ahimelech reports David to Saul immediately
Ahimelech demands payment for his help
questions.correctAnswer: Ahimelech provides spiritual resources and counsel to David
questions.explanation: Ahimelech supports David by providing consecrated bread and the sword of Goliath, demonstrating the priest’s role as spiritual caretaker (1 Samuel 21:1-9). This aligns with biblical teachings on priestly intercession (Hebrews 7:23-25), the church’s role in sustaining the faithful (Ephesians 4:11-12), and God’s provision through His appointed servants (Acts 13:2).

questions.question: What does David’s feigning madness before Achish teach about the use of wisdom and discernment in difficult situations?
options: Sometimes prudence requires strategic actions to preserve life
Faith forbids any deception under any circumstance
One must always confront enemies boldly
Avoidance of conflict is a sign of weakness
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes prudence requires strategic actions to preserve life
questions.explanation: David’s act of feigning madness shows that prudence and wisdom can be used to navigate danger (Ecclesiastes 9:18, Matthew 10:16). It reflects biblical endorsement of wise conduct without compromising faith (Proverbs 22:3), and God’s sovereignty working through human decisions (Daniel 6:22).
